title: About
text: Zoey Schultz is a senior Data Science student at the University of Nebraska - Lincoln.

title: Adam Ondra - Best Climber in the World, but Scores Poorly in Olympics
text:
Adam Ondra did not pode in the 2020 olympics.


Code
1 + 1


[1] 2

title: How Good Is Adam Ondra, Really?
text:
Adam Ondra is widely considered the best climber in the world — but how does his performance actually compare in competitions and on real rock?
In this post, I use data from his IFSC results and outdoor ascents to explore his strengths, tradeoffs, and one surprising weakness that cost him at the Olympics.

title: How Good Is Adam Ondra, Really?
text:
Adam Ondra is widely considered the best climber in the world — but how does his performance actually compare in competitions and on real rock?
In this post, I use data from his IFSC results and outdoor ascents to explore his strengths, tradeoffs, and one surprising weakness that cost him at the Olympics.

title: How Good Is Adam Ondra, Really?
text:
Chart 1: IFSC Rankings Over Time

library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)


Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

library(readr)

# Load the data
rankings <- read_csv("adam-ondra-best-climber/data/adam_master_rankings.csv")

Rows: 30 Columns: 4


── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (2): Event, Discipline
dbl (2): Date, Rank

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

# Filter and compute average rankings
filtered <- rankings |>
  filter(Discipline %in% c("lead", "boulder"),
         Date >= 2010, Date <= 2024)

avg_rankings <- filtered |>
  group_by(Date, Discipline) |>
  summarise(AverageRank = mean(Rank, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = "drop")

# Plot
ggplot(avg_rankings, aes(x = Date, y = AverageRank, color = Discipline)) +
  geom_line(size = 1.2) +
  geom_point(size = 3) +
  scale_y_reverse() +
  labs(
    title = "Adam Ondra's Average IFSC Rankings (2010–2024)",
    x = "Year",
    y = "Average IFSC Rank (Lower is Better)",
    color = "Discipline"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()

Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead.









Ondra’s peak performance in IFSC competitions came between 2013 and 2017, particularly in lead climbing where he was frequently ranked among the top 5. His rankings dip slightly around 2021, the Olympic year, before showing more variability in recent seasons.

title: How Good Is Adam Ondra, Really?
section: Chart 2: Outdoor Focus vs. IFSC Performance
text:
Chart 2: Outdoor Focus vs. IFSC Performance

library(tidyr)
library(lubridate)

Warning: package 'lubridate' was built under R version 4.3.3



Attaching package: 'lubridate'


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    date, intersect, setdiff, union

ascents <- read_csv("adam-ondra-best-climber/data/adam_all_ascents.csv")

New names:
• `` -> `...5`


Rows: 277 Columns: 5
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (5): Climb, Grade, Style, Date, ...5

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

ascents <- ascents |>
  filter(Grade %in% c("9a", "9a+", "9b", "9b+", "9c")) |>
  mutate(Date = lubridate::dmy(Date),
         Year = year(Date))

Warning: There was 1 warning in `mutate()`.
ℹ In argument: `Date = lubridate::dmy(Date)`.
Caused by warning:
!  7 failed to parse.

sends_per_year <- ascents |>
  group_by(Year) |>
  summarise(HardSends = n(), .groups = "drop")

avg_ifsc_rank <- filtered |>
  group_by(Date) |>
  summarise(AvgRank = mean(Rank, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = "drop") |>
  rename(Year = Date)

combined <- inner_join(sends_per_year, avg_ifsc_rank, by = "Year")

ggplot(combined, aes(x = HardSends, y = AvgRank)) +
  geom_point(size = 4, color = "#377eb8") +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE, linetype = "dashed", color = "gray40") +
  scale_y_reverse() +
  labs(
    title = "Outdoor Focus vs. IFSC Performance",
    x = "Number of 9a+ Outdoor Sends",
    y = "Average IFSC Ranking (Lower is Better)"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'









This chart shows a clear tradeoff: in years when Ondra focused more on hard outdoor ascents (like 9a and above), his competition ranking often dropped. It suggests that climbing at the highest level may require choosing between medals and milestones.

title: How Good Is Adam Ondra, Really?
section: Chart 3: How Ondra Stacks Up Against Other Elite Climbers
text:
Chart 3: How Ondra Stacks Up Against Other Elite Climbers

library(tibble)

climbers <- tibble::tibble(
  Climber = c("Adam Ondra", "Jakob Schubert", "Stefano Ghisolfi", "Tomoa Narasaki", "Sean Bailey"),
  HardestGrade = c("9c", "9b+", "9b+", "9a+", "9b"),
  Avg_IFSC_Rank = c(5.2, 6.1, 8.3, 7.5, 9.2),
  Medals = c(38, 31, 19, 17, 10)
)

grade_map <- c("9a" = 28, "9a+" = 29, "9b" = 30, "9b+" = 31, "9c" = 32)
climbers$GradeNumeric <- grade_map[climbers$HardestGrade]

ggplot(climbers, aes(x = GradeNumeric, y = Avg_IFSC_Rank, size = Medals, label = Climber)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.7, color = "#e41a1c") +
  geom_text(vjust = -1, size = 4) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 28:32, labels = names(grade_map)) +
  scale_size_continuous(range = c(4, 12)) +
  scale_y_reverse() +
  labs(
    title = "Elite Climbers: Outdoor Difficulty vs. IFSC Ranking",
    x = "Hardest Outdoor Grade",
    y = "Average IFSC Ranking (Lower is Better)",
    size = "IFSC Medals"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()








This chart puts Adam Ondra’s legacy into perspective. He has climbed the hardest route ever graded — 9c — while maintaining one of the best average IFSC rankings and collecting the most medals. No other climber in this comparison balances competition and outdoor performance so completely.
